What are you doing?  There are a number of other video on demand westerns I would like to buy as well.Derek

reviewText: Richard Boone carries this rather unevenWestern, with superb support from a stellarcast, although Whitman's role is disappointinglysmall - THE COMANCHEROS is a better choicefor Whitman fans. Boone's is a rare blendof tough-guy savagery and rough-edgedhumanity, and contemporary Hollywood is starved forthe authentic manliness that actors likeBoone once brought to the screen. Factor inhis distinctively droll humor, and you havethat indefinable Star Power so elusive today.Granted, the film - as noted in previousreviews - is startlingly violent, but itis not gratuitously so. On the contrary,the movie trades Hollywood-style storytellingfor realism. There are no "good soldiers" or"bad Indians" here - only flawed human beingsstruggling to survive against insurmountableodds.
summary: It's Boone's Film All the Way

reviewText: Richard Boone was one of those rare actors who could liven up every movie he was in by his mere presence, and he easily steals the show in "Rio Conchos," a film otherwise known for being the film debut of Jim Brown, who was still a full-time running back for the Cleveland Browns when this was made in 1964.The plot is reminiscent of John Wayne's "The Comancheros" from a couple of years earlier, down to co-star Stuart Whitman. Actually, Whitman and Brown play the straight men here while Boone hams it up as a former Confederate officer, bent on revenge against the Apaches for killing his family. A group of renegade ex-Confederates, led by Edmond O'Brien, a former officer with Boone, have stolen a bunch of Army rifles and want to sell them to the Apaches. The army dispatches Whitman and Brown to foil this plan, and Boone agrees to accompany them. Also along for the ride with them is Anthony Franciosa as a half-breed who feels there's money to be made here.There's plenty of fairly sadistic (for the early 1960s) violence here as Boone and the Apaches hate each other with a passion. However, Boone never becomes one-dimensional. Instead, as he usually does, he seeks to put a bemused spin on nearly every line reading, as if he knows he is always aware of just how bizarre the situation his party is in. As a result, pedestrian dialogue becomes a pleasure to hear. Boone gets plenty of support from Franciosa and O'Brien, who also churn the script with relish, overacting a storm. In some movies, this would prove fatal. However, the net effect of their overacting is to give the film an almost surreal feel, much like some of the spaghetti Westerns that were just beginning to make the rounds. Director Gordon Douglas knows enough to stay out of their way during the dialogue scenes and put together some exciting action sequences."Rio Conchos" came along towards the end of the big budget Western era, as pretty much everyone but John Wayne had abandoned the genre, and before the onslaught of spaghetti Westerns. Although few remember the movie today, those that do, like myself, savor its mix of action and bizarre quirkiness that have given it near cult status.

reviewText: Rio Conchos is a very good western with violence that is still a bit startling when you see it today, much less in 1964.  A wagon train carrying 2,000 new repeating rifles has been stolen causing the army to worry where they went.  Two soldiers team up with a drunken ex-Confederate officer and a bandit to track down the missing guns.  While searching, they discover a Confederate officer, Colonel Theron Pardee, who is trying to start the Civil War all over again by giving Apache warriors the new repeating rifles.  The small group must try and stop him as they battle Mexican bandits, Apache warriors, and even themselves.  Rio Conchos is a grim western with a very realistic tone.  The violence seems out of place for the time, but it is still very effective, most notably in the torture scene towards the end.  Jerry Goldsmith turns in another excellent score, sometimes reminiscent of Bandolero.  For an enjoyable yet dark western, check out Rio Conchos.Richard Boone gives an excellent performance as Jim Lassiter, the ex-Confederate officer who joins up with the army.  At the same time, Lassiter is dealing with the death of his family at the hands of the Apaches.  Stuart Whitman is also very good as army Captain Haven, the leader of the small bunch.  Anthony Franciosa stars as Rodriguez, the bandit who joins Lassiter and Haven.  In his first movie since leaving football, Jim Brown plays Sgt. Franklyn, Haven's right hand man.  Edmond O'Brien stars as Colonel Pardee, who hopes to begin the Civil War again.  The movie also stars Wende Wagner, Rodolfo Acosta, Vito Scotti, and Kevin Hagen.  The VHS is in pan-n-scan so it isn't of the best quality.  This movie begs for a DVD widescreen release.  For an excellent western with a very good cast, check out Rio Conchos!

reviewText: Stuart Whitman, Richard Boone, Jim Brown and Anthony Franciosa  are well cast in this tough western tale. Edmund O'Brien is also a stand out. Don't miss it.
